title: Magnetic field - varying radius of loop of wire

content.description: A wire is formed into a circular loop of radius <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>. The loop is then attached to a source of constant potential difference <math alttext="delta V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></math>, and the resulting current <math alttext="I sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> through the loop creates a magnetic field of magnitude <math alttext="B sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>B</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> at the center of the loop. The same wire is then used to form a second circular loop of radius <math alttext="2 R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>R</mi></math>. If this second loop is connected to the same source of constant potential difference <math alttext="delta V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></math>, how does the current <math alttext="I sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> in the second loop and the magnetic field <math alttext="B sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>B</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> at the center of the second loop compare to <math alttext="I sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="B sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>B</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, respectively?
